column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.
Entering this country from outside an EU Member State or Schengen Associated country.
Note: as of 1 March, the same rules as for travel from EU and Schengen Associated countries will apply.
Document checklist
Travellers must provide all the following documents: 1. Fill in the EU Digital Passenger Locator Form before travelling
. 2. A valid 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' (EUDCC), or documents equivalent to the 'EU Digital COVID Certificate'. Details in the sections below.
Holders of 'EU Digital Covid Certificates' (EUDCC), or documents equivalent to the 'EU Digital COVID Certificate', can enter Italy without being subject to quarantine, if their EUDCC contains one of the following:
Proof of full vaccination;
Proof of recovery from COVID-19. Validity: 180 days (6 months) from the first positive swab.
A negative result to a pre-departure molecular test (valid 72 hours) or to a rapid antigen test (valid 48 hours).
Entering this country without the EU Digital COVID certificate or with a certificate not compliant with national requirements: travellers who do not hold the documents requested must self-isolate for 5 days, at the address indicated on the Passenger Locator Form, and perform an antigen or molecular test at the end of the self-isolation period.
These rules apply until 31 March 2022.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation-subject to category. No more quarantine for travelers arriving from non-EU countries. Only a standard Green Pass will be needed to enter Italy: either proof of vaccination, recovery from COVID-19, or a negative test.
If you cannot present evidence of vaccination OR a negative test OR a COVID-19 recovery certificate, you will need to:
• remain in self-isolation for 5 days
• call the COVID-19 - Regional telephone information hotline to notify the Prevention Department of the local health authority of your entry into Italy as you will be under medical supervision
• take another PCR or rapid lateral flow test at the end of the 5 days’ self-isolation. If the test is negative, you can leave self-isolation
column4:
THIS COUNTRY IS READY TO CONNECT TO THE EU DIGITAL COVID CERTIFICATE GATEWAY
Proof of full vaccination. Accepted vaccines: vaccines approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA): Comirnaty (BioNTech and Pfizer), Nuvaxovid (Novavax), Spikevax (Moderna), Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca), COVID19 vaccine Janssen; vaccines considered equivalent in Italy.
Validity: 270 days (9 months) after the primary vaccination series is completed. Vaccination certificates with booster doses are valid until further notice. Note: to access public places in Italy, certificates with a full primary vaccination series are valid for 6 months. Please, consult the Measures section for further details.
column5:
Latest News: Government to relax COVID-19 restrictions for third-country nationals from 1 March (SVI, 23.02.2022).

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU:

Documents equivalent to the 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' (EUDCC) are also accepted, if they meet the same requirements listed above for the EUDCC. Certificates or recovery from COVID-19 must meet the criteria established by Italy's Ministry of Health.

Travellers who do not hold the documents requested must self-isolate for 5 days, at the address indicated on the Passenger Locator Form, and perform an antigen or molecular test at the end of the self-isolation period.

*Transit:

Contact Point for Italy:
COVID-19 Information line



*From Third Countries:

Entry rules

To discover specific entry conditions depending on your country of departure, fill in the online questionnaire on Viaggiare Sicuri.

Children younger than 6 are exempt from pre-departure testing requirements. They are also exempt from self-isolation if the parent travelling with them is not subject to self-isolation.

Children aged 6 or over must provide a pre-departure test. If the parent travelling with them is not subject to self-isolation, children are also exempt from this requirement, including if they are not vaccinated.

 

Document checklist

Travellers must provide all the following documents:

  1. Fill in the Passenger Locator Form before travelling

  2. Provide an 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' (EUDCC) or equivalent documents containing one of the following:

    Proof of full vaccination
    Validity: 270 days (9 months) after the primary vaccination series is completed. Vaccination certificates with booster doses are valid until further notice.
    Note: to access public places in Italy, certificates with a full primary vaccination series are valid for 6 months. Please, consult the Measures section for further details.
    Accepted vaccines:
    vaccines approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA): Comirnaty (BioNTech and Pfizer), Nuvaxovid (Novavax), Spikevax (Moderna), Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca), COVID-19 vaccine Janssen; vaccines considered equivalent: Covishield, Fiocruz, R-Covi.

    Proof of recovery from COVID-19.
    Validity: 180 days (6 months).
    Certificates of recovery different from the EUDCC and from equivalent documents must meet the criteria established by Italy's Ministry of Health.

    A negative result to a pre-departure molecular test (valid 72 hours) or to a rapid antigen test (valid 48 hours)

Travellers who do not provide any of these documents must self-isolate for 5 days, at the address indicated on the Passenger Locator Form, and perform an antigen or molecular test at the end of the self-isolation period.

These rules apply until 31 March 2022.

Internal Restrictions:
The host government has announced that the COVID-19 state of emergency in Italy, which had been declared on 31 January 2020, will come to an end on 31 March 2022. With this decision, the following key milestones have thus far been established (with a more detailed roadmap for returning to normal still to come):
• 1 March: No more quarantine for travelers arriving from non-EU countries. Only a standard Green Pass will be needed to enter Italy: either proof of vaccination, recovery from COVID-19, or a negative test.
• 1 April: 1st day of post-emergency phase. Masks will no longer be required outdoors and the system for different color regions will be abolished. Schools will no longer implement quarantine for close contact and FFP2 masks will no longer be required in classrooms.
• 15 June: the requirement for a Super Green Pass will continue to apply until 15 June for persons over 50 to go to work. The vaccine mandate for persons over 50 will also cease to apply on this date.
Further details on the easing of restrictions, including the scaling back of Green Passes, are yet to be defined and will be communicated as soon as definitive decisions are announced.
Italian Government signed an Ordinance which is in effect from Friday, 11 February to 31 March 2022.
It stipulates the following regarding mask-wearing throughout the country:
• Face masks must be worn in all indoor spaces, with the exception of private households
• While local laws may introduce more stringent requirements, individuals are now simply required to have a mask on them at all times, which may be worn outdoors in situations where crowds or gatherings may form.
On Friday, 4 February 2022, Italy Government published a legislative decree (attached in its original Italian) , which took effect from Saturday, 5 February 2022. It stipulates the following:
Extended validity of EU Digital COVID Certificates
• EU Digital COVID Certificates for people with three doses now have indefinite validity; in other words, they no longer expire.
• EU Digital COVID Certificates for people with at least two doses plus registered recovery from COVID-19 now have indefinite validity; in other words, they no longer expire.
Foreigners with expired Super Green Pass/ non-EMA recognized vaccines
For individuals originating from a foreign country who have a valid certificate from relevant foreign health authorities confirming:
• recovery from COVID-19 from over 6 months ago (i.e. expired Super Green Pass)
• completion of the primary vaccination cycle with an EMA-recognized vaccine from over 6 months ago (i.e. expired Super Green Pass)
• OR have received non-EMA-recognized vaccines
access will be allowed to venues/services requiring a Super Green Pass upon presentation of a negative antigen or molecular COVID-19 Test from the previous 48 hours.
A COVID-19 test is not required to access services in cases where individuals have received two doses of an EMA-recognized vaccine plus have proof of subsequently recovering from COVID-19.
Red Zones: Red Zone restrictions do not apply to those in possession of a Super Green Pass.
Positive Cases in Schools: • Nurseries and pre-schools: If there are 5 or more positive cases in a class, distance learning takes effect for a period of 5 days.
• Primary/elementary schools: If there are 5 or more positive cases in a class, distance learning + quarantine takes effect for a period of 5 days only for students lacking a valid Super Green Pass. A negative COVID-19 test is required to return to school in-person.
• Secondary/middle schools and above: If there are 2 or more positive cases in a class, distance learning + quarantine takes effect for a period of 5 days only for students lacking a valid Super Green Pass. A negative COVID-19 test is required to return to school in-person.
Please recall that whenever any positive cases are confirmed in a class, regardless of the number of cases or the age group, classmates must take a COVID-19 test if symptoms arise OR on the 5th day from first contact with the positive case.
Please also recall that access to learning institutions is prohibited for anyone with a body temperature over 37.5 degrees Celsius.
Orange Zones: Zones classified as having an ‘elevated' risk. In these zones, a Super Green Pass is needed to:
• Access malls and shopping centers on the weekends
• Play contact sports outdoors
Public transport is capped at a maximum occupancy rate of 50%
At least a standard Green Pass is needed to leave one’s municipality (both within the region or outside of the region) EXCEPT for work, health, or other urgent reasons. *Yellow Zones: Zones classified as having a 'moderate' risk: Calabria, Campania, Emilia Romagna, Lazio, Liguria, Marche, Puglia, Sardinia, Tuscany, Veneto, and the autonomous provinces of Bolzano and Trento
*White Zones: Zones classified as having a ‘low’ level of risk: Basilicata, Molise, and Umbria.
